subject: JUnit test executor.
msgSnippet: Hi everyone, I m currently working on a test management application which aims to provide a common, simple to use GUI to execute tests on a multitude of test
messageBody:
Hi everyone,

I'm currently working on a test management application which aims to
provide a common, simple to use GUI to execute tests on a multitude
of test tools.

There are a few of us developing this application and its initial
concept was born out of the need to drive hardware test tools in a
telecoms lab, so our previous efforts have been to drive these
hardware tools (MGTS, DCT & EVO). Though we feel there is scope to
broaden its use and we aim to develop "interfaces" to control
software test tools (such as JUnit).

Since the application itself is developed in Java and we already
have a suite of JUnit tests; we thought writing a JUnit interface
would be a good first step. Though before we get too far in to it,
it would be good to get other peoples views / thoughts on such a
tool for JUnit?

Without going into too much detail, the application would
effectively provide a web based test management front-end for JUnit
(i.e. high level test case creation, execution and results). There
would be some initial setup, as users would need to mirror (either
manually or by using helper scripts) their JUnit test / class names
in our application (so the application knows which method / class to
execute for each test / suite of tests and what to store the result
against), but once that's done it would just be a case of executing
all your JUnit tests through our GUI.

If anyone gets a spare few minutes, it would be good to get some
thoughts on what people think about the general concept? i.e.
providing a graphical, simple to use test executor / results store
(including metrics and chart generation) tool for JUnit. Do people
think it will be beneficial?

I'll be more than happy to provide more information on the
application etc and we will be looking for people to try the system
(with JUnit) in the New Year.

Cheers,
Les.
